On Apr 13, 2007, at 5:15 AM, Jason Gauci wrote:

> OK, actually I wrote a couple of lua programs to figure this out.

I did too.  Unfortunately I made a typo, which you caught, that  
should have said (1+1) = 2.  That's what I get for doing something  
manually rather than letting a machine do it for me.

You made a mistake in your program by saying H1 = I + H0; whereas, if  
you look at my original post, H1 = I.  For clarification, please see  
my original post, where I present the network, the sorted list of  
nodes, and the proper update algorithm.

Here's my program:

#!/usr/bin/env ruby

$i = 0
$h0 = 0
$h1 = 0
$o = 0

40.times do |iter|
         $i = 1
         $h0 = $i + $h1
         $h1 = $i
         $o = $h0 + $h1
         puts "#{$i} #{$h0} #{$h1} #{$o}"
end


Here's its output:

1 1 1 2
1 2 1 3
1 2 1 3
1 2 1 3
1 2 1 3
...

It's painfully clear to me  that with this network (and many others),  
my activation algorithm is producing the proper/expected result,  
recurrent node included!

I wanted to look at the network you actually used, where H1 is input  
by both I and H0.  Then I get matching results with you:

1 1 2 3
1 3 4 7
1 5 6 11
1 7 8 15
1 9 10 19
...

And, after looking at it for a second, they make perfect sense.  The  
link you added was a forward link, from H0 to H1.  Everything in this  
network too works properly.  H1 is indeed an accumulator (part of the  
beauty of recurrent connections), and of course with sigmoidal  
activation, would simply max out at 1.0 (as long as the 1.0 inputs  
continued!).  So, again, everything works as expected.  (It's clear  
that H0 is updated BEFORE H1, therefore the recurrent link from H1  
back to H0 will indeed use its "prior" activation).

One last thing.  To sort a network, I consider it a cyclic digraph  
where the output nodes are all children of the root.  Then do at  
depth-first search, and as you encounter leaf nodes, add them to the  
end of your sorted node list.  Pretty simple.

Now, I don't want to belabor this any more, I believe my point is  
clear - I understand it anyway.  I only kept going this long because  
I was just trying to help you or others understand; therefore, I'll  
let this thread die from my end of the world.

--Steve
--Apple-Mail-1-601634542
